results.title: The Enormous Crocodile
results.brief_description: When the Enormous Crocodile boasts that he is going to eat a child for his lunch the other jungle animals decide to foil his dastardly plot. Children will delight in the exploits of Humpy Rumpy, Muggle Wump and the Roly-Poly bird. The animation is based on the original illustrations of Quentin Blake for another of Roald Dahl’s entertaining moral tales.

results.title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser = Jeder fur sich und Gott gegen alle
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog, Walter Saxer and Werner Herzog Filmproduktion
results.brief_description: Regarded as Herzog’s finest film, “The Enigma of Kasper Hauser” is based on a true story about a 19th Century genius. His origins shrouded in mystery, Kasper Hauser was found wandering the streets of Nuremberg in 1820. Without speech, nor any sign of parentage, Hauser immediately becomes the object of scrutiny from the town authorities. After learning to talk he tells of living in a cellar, displaying no signs of having had any contact with other human beings since childhood. In his attempts to adjust to adult life, he reveals a highly advanced intelligence and alternative, almost prophetic, vision. Herzog demonstrates his fascination with misfits, and as the story develops, the confrontation between innocence and corruption intensifies. Cast includes Bruno S, Walter Ladengast and Brigitte Mira. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: The English patient [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Saul Zaentz and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Based on Michael Ondaatje’s Booker prize-winning novel, “The English Patient” is a sumptuous romance set during the second world war in the deserts of North Africa and the rolling hills of Tuscany. Hana (Juliette Binoche), a shell-shocked Canadian nurse decides to stay in an abandoned villa to nurse a mysterious English patient (Ralph Fiennes) who is burned beyond recognition and doesn’t remember his name. Gradually we learn the truth of his identity and of his doomed love affair with Katherine Mansfield (Kristen Scott Thomas). (Awards: Winner of 9 Oscars at the 1996 Academy Awards, including Best Film, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress - Juliette Binoche and Best Cinematography for Australian John Seale)

results.title: The English language: story of its development
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the English language from its roots in the Anglo and Saxon tongues, through its infusion of French and Latin, and finally its emergence as a printed language which is still growing and changing. The influence of Church monks, William the Conqueror, Chaucer and Shakespeare are discussed.

results.title: The English language: patterns of usage
results.brief_description: The words a person uses, their pronunciation, the construction of phrases and sentences, dialects and speech rhythms are all aspects of usage and style. In this film we see how speech styles and acceptability vary with individuals and culture groups, and in different language situations.

results.title: The English inn
results.creator_credit: Muriel Baker, James Carr, Sydney Box and Verity Films
results.brief_description: The inn is the centre of life in the towns and villages of England. Carved designs and paintings by artists of long ago can still be seen today in these inns. Most of the more pretentious inns were built along the old coaching routes, where they formed a vital part of the communication system.

results.title: The England of Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: John Taylor, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: A.L. Rowse, the eminent historian, has written, “The Elizabethan Age is not something dead and apart from us…Wherever one goes in England there are visible memorials of what those men and women were when they were alive, houses they built, things they made and wore, objects they cherished, patterns they imposed upon the very landscape.” Some of the visible traces as well as something of the spirit of that England of Elizabeth I, Drake, Raleigh and Shakespeare, are recorded in this film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Taylor, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films

results.title: The Engineering of agreement. What would you say?
results.creator_credit: Jodie Copelan, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Obtaining the agreement of others is vital in the everyday work situation and in such fields as sales; the value of considering the other person’s point of view and of establishing two way communication. Two real-life interviews show the right and wrong approaches, while a trailer provides opportunities for discussing common difficulties.

results.title: The Engineer and the atom
results.brief_description: The role of engineers in a series of atomic projects, including Calder Hall, Dounreay, and the new series of stations being built for the Electricity Authority are featured. The need for new techniques in building skill, using a greater degree of precision than ever before, and new materials capable of standing up to intense strain and powerful radiation is emphasised. No other credits available.
